awd_titl_txt: Lift Management for Unsteady Translating Wings Using a Rotating, Swept Wing Tip
awd_abstract_narration:
Drone aircraft have an ever-increasing role in society, with both civilian and defense applications.  A key research area is the development of small-scale, agile drones that can maneuver alone or in groups in complex environments.  Such scenarios include search-and-rescue operations, tracking a toxic gas plume, or collecting large-scale data such as city traffic patterns.  However, these vehicles are susceptible to loss of control during maneuvers because of turbulence and wind gusts. This project will seek to better understand and prevent this loss of control by modifying the wing-tip shape in real-time in order to control the lift force in these scenarios.  Imaging and lift measurements in a water tank with a scaled wing model will lead to a predictive mathematical model for improved future flight-control systems.  This project also has an outreach plan that focuses on mentoring female high-school, undergraduate, and graduate students and engaging them through hands-on research.

The objective of the proposed research is to investigate the viability of a variable wing tip to control the flow coherence and lift for a dynamically-stalled wing during high-angle-of-attack, unsteady translation.  In this scenario, a swirling, low-pressure leading-edge vortex forms over the wing and yields large lift, but then sheds.  The proposed moveable wingtip will exploit tip-vortex control to increase lift for high-angle-of-attack maneuvers or reduce lift for gust alleviation.  The proposed variable wing tip is unique, combining rotation with aft sweep, which should produce a more attached and coherent vortex flow and substantial lift control.  Experiments will be performed with scaled models in a water tank, using dye visualization, force measurements, and stereo particle image velocimetry for 3D velocity reconstructions.  The experimental results will be used to develop a predictive model for improved flight-control methods.

por.por_cntn:
This project tested the ability of wing with a moving tip to modify the outboard flow and change the lift to handle gusts.  The wing had a rectangular main portion and variable wingtip (Fig. 1).  The tip was a rotating panel, moving in the same plane as the wing, with a pivot at the front or leading-edge corner of the main wing.  It was inspired by birds, but was much simpler and rigid.  All tests were done for stalled wings at high incidence, to understand more extreme situations with wing flow separation.  For headwind gusts, which produce unwanted higher lift, the panel starts extended then rotates inward shortly after the gust; this reduces lift.  To counteract tailwind gusts, which lower lift, the panel starts inward then rotates outward after gust initiation (Fig. 1).  Rotation was chosen because prior work showed that, if it was relatively faster than the wain-wing speed, for outward motion it would produce a coherent vortex (swirling flow) to boost lift.  Also, indications were that if the front edge of the tip panel were swept backward, this might promote flow along the edge and vortex attachment.

The application is small, uninhabited air vehicles (UAVs).  These autonomous vehicles, acting alone or in swarms, could greatly increase our ability to gather information in complex environments like urban canopies, disaster sites, or forests, e.g., for collecting scientific data, search-and-rescue operations, or tracking a toxic gas plume.  However, these settings may have strong gusts on the scale of the drone's speed and size, to which small UAVs are vulnerable.  To have high maneuverability and manage gusts, more aggressive control strategies are needed.  This project's shape-changing wing was tested as one method for achieving this.

The technical approach was scaled experiments in a towing tank, where a wing model with a motorized tip was moved in water at a speed that produces scaled physics matching a smaller wing in air.  To emulate a headwind gust, the wing surged forward, and to mimic a tailwind gust it slowed.  A load cell provided the time-varying lift.  Flow patterns were captured on video by injecting colored dye around the wing.  Next, cutting-edge 3D imaging equipment from an NSF Major Research Instrumentation grant quantitatively measured the 3D flow velocity around the wing.  Extremely small fluorescent tracer particles were illuminated by a strobed laser volume, then tracked with 4 high-speed cameras.

The research produced a physics-driven, simplified model of rotating-wing lift, e.g., the wingtip only, which is useful for future studies and was the first to capture the unsteady, 3D aspects.  Next, force measurements were done for step-up (headwind) and step-down (tailwind) gusts of different rates.  They showed the step-up lift is similar to a start from rest, and early actuation-in lowers the first gust peak, while actuation halfway through the gust gives a sustained lift reduction (Fig. 2).  A shorter, aspect-ratio 2 wing yields a greater relative lift reduction, but less sustained than for 4.  For step-down (tailwind) gusts, earlier actuation-out can overshoot the recovery, and the moving tip can give a prolonged lift boost.  Gust mitigation for actuation-in ranges from about 20-35%, while for actuation-out it is 20-80%; therefore, the tip panel can significantly alleviate gusts.  From the flow measurements the strength or circulation of the nearby lift-generating vortex flow was calculated.  For step-up gusts, tip actuation-in reduces circulation over the outboard wing, and sheds the tip-region vortex flow; this causes the desired lift decrease.  The tip actuation-out during step-down gusts creates temporarily-higher circulation over the outboard span, and a more attached and coherent tip-panel vortex flow.  This explains the higher lift for gust mitigation.  Actuation-out is more successful because it creates a new, more attached outboard vortex flow that can be varied, while actuation-in is beneficial but can only shed the existing near-tip flow.  Overall, this research showed that a morphing shape, namely a rotating, swept wingtip, can substantially alter the unsteady outboard vortex flow, to enhance lift performance and mitigate gusts.  The results were disseminated at several conferences and via journal papers.

The project supported 2 Ph.D. students, including 1 female who graduated, and involved 6 undergraduate researchers among which 1 was female.  All received training on equipment and in fluid dynamics, and mentoring about best-practices, graduate school, and STEM careers.  The outreach focused on engaging underrepresented groups in hands-on aerospace-related activities.  Two events involved underrepresented middle- and high-school students in a rubber-band-powered helicopter challenge to build them and compete in time-aloft trials.  Two others engaged undergraduates from Women in Science and Engineering performing dye and particle visualization in the lab.  One held a dinner discussion with a senior female faculty member on women in STEM careers.  These activities were well-received, and it is hoped that they have supported and encouraged students to seek continuing STEM education and careers.
